title: Word of the Day | plait
title_page: Word of the Day | plait - The New York Times
text:
plait •\ˈplāt, ˈplat\• noun and verb
noun: a hairdo formed by braiding or twisting the hair
verb: make by braiding or interlacing
verb: weave into plaits
The word plait has appeared in three New York Times articles in the past year, including on May 26 in “It’s a Turban, It’s a Dress (It’s a Scarf)” by Ruth La Ferla:
Mariangela Melato could work a scarf like Salome. In “Swept Away,” Lina Wertmüller’s 1974 screen exploration of class and gender warfare, her character, a castaway, makes do mostly with a single wardrobe item, an outsize scarf that she presses into service as a head wrap, a sultry halter dress, a lens-fogging slit-to-the-hip sarong and, when the waters get choppy, a sheltering cocoon. … Inevitably, as it now seems, retailers have taken to touting scarves as the ultimate multitaskers, drawing attention to their shape-shifting properties and encouraging shoppers, through online videos and mannequin displays, to tweak, twist, loop, plait and knot them to form summer mufflers, cowl-neck blouses, turbans, halters, sarongs and goddess-worthy maxidress.
